mainlistitem.desc: What do you do in the summer?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 1: What do you do in the summer?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Pat Miller.
Pat: Hello, Kathy. Hi, Max.
Kathy: Pat, how's school going?
Pat: It's going well. I'm working hard but I enjoy it.
Kathy: Do you get a vacation?
Pat: Sure I do. Our summer vacation begins in June. It lasts until September. We also have a two-week vacation in December.
Kathy: What do you do during your summer vacation?
Pat: In the summer, I like to go swimming. I like hot weather, and I love going to the beach.

comprehensionitem.question: Does Pat enjoy school?
When does her summer vacation begin?
What does she like to do in the summer?

grammaritem.question: School is _____ well.
Summer vacation _____ until September.
What do you do ______ your summer vacation?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Pat: In the summer, I like to go swimming. I like hot weather, and I love going to the beach.
Kathy: How about winter? What do you do in the winter?
Pat: I sometimes go skiing, but I don't like cold weather. When it's cold, I prefer to stay inside.
Kathy: Sure. Me too!

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0301B_Q1.mp3|Does Pat like cold weather?
NDE0301B_Q2.mp3|What does Pat do when it's cold?
NDE0301B_Q3.mp3|Which does she prefer, winter or summer?

grammaritem.answer: What do you do in the winter?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: We're back with our guest, Pat Miller. What's your favorite season, Pat?
Pat: My favorite season? Well, I like summer a lot, but I think my favorite season is spring.
Kathy: Why is that?
Pat: Well, it's warm. The flowers bloom and the leaves on the trees turn green. In spring, people come here to see the cherry blossoms.
Kathy: Do you like fall?
Pat: I like fall. I like to see the leaves turn colors. It's a beautiful time of year, but it starts to get cool. I don't like cool weather very much.
Kathy: What about winter?
Pat: Oh, I hate winter! It's cold and dark. I hate it!

comprehensionitem.question: What is Pat's favorite season?
When do the leaves turn colors?
Which season does Pat like the least?

grammaritem.question: People come here ______ the cherry blossoms.
It ______ to get cool in the fall.
I _____ like cool weather very much.

mainlistitem.desc: Can you tell us about your photographs?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 2: Can you tell us about your photographs?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Simon Tompkins. Good morning, Mr. Tompkins.
Simon: Simon. Call me Simon.
Kathy: I see you have some photographs with you, Simon. Can you tell us about them?

Simon: Certainly. These photographs are from my new series: Twenty-Four Hours on the Farm. They show the farm at different times of the day. For example, here is a photo of a farm in early morning. It's six a.m., the beginning of the day. The sun is very low in the sky. Through the window, we can see the farmer and his family.
Kathy: Right. They are eating breakfast.
Simon: And the farm animals are waking up.
Kathy: I see. In the yard, the chickens are looking for food. And the rooster is crowing!

comprehensionitem.question: What does Simon do?
When was the photograph taken?
What is the farmer doing in the photograph?

grammaritem.question: Here is a _____ of a farm in early morning.
The farmer and his family __________ breakfast.
The chickens ___ looking for food.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Simon: Let's look at another photo.
Kathy: What's this one?
Simon: Can you guess?
Kathy: Well, the sun is high in the sky. The people are working in the field. What are they doing?
Simon: They're picking tomatoes.
Kathy: Is it in the afternoon?
Simon: Yes, it is. It's about two o'clock in the afternoon.
Kathy: It's a nice picture, Simon. Thank you. What about this one? This is in the evening, isn't it?
Simon: Yes. The sun is going down and the sky is beautiful. The animals are going back to the barn. Some of the workers are leaving.
Kathy: I like this picture a lot.
Simon: Thank you.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0302B_Q1.mp3|What are the people doing in the field?
NDE0302B_Q2.mp3|What time of day is it in the first photo?
option: It's two o'clock in the afternoon.
comprehensionitem.answer: It's two o'clock in the afternoon.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0302B_Q3.mp3|What is happening in the second photo?
option: The animals are going back to the barn.
The farmer is working in the field.
comprehensionitem.answer: The animals are going back to the barn.

grammaritem.answer: The sun is high in the sky.
The people are working in the field.
The animals are going back to the barn.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Let's look at one more.
Simon: OK. In this one, everything is dark. There are stars in the sky and the house is dark. Everyone is asleep.
Kathy: Look. There's the moon!
Simon: Yes, you can see the moon behind that tree. The moon is just coming up.
Kathy: What's your favorite time of day?
Simon: My favorite time of day? That's a good question. My favorite time of day is morning. Early morning.
Kathy: Why is that?
Simon: Mornings are very beautiful. It's quiet and you can hear the birds singing. It's a very special time of day for me.

comprehensionitem.question: What time of day is it in the photo?
Where is the moon in the photo?
option: It is coming up behind a tree.
It is high in the sky.
comprehensionitem.answer: It is coming up behind a tree.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Simon's favorite time of day?
option: early morning, when the sun is rising
early evening, when the sun is setting
mid-day, when the sun is high in the sky
comprehensionitem.answer: early morning, when the sun is rising

grammaritem.question: _____ stars in the sky and the house is dark.
The moon is just ______ up.
You can hear the birds _______.

mainlistitem.desc: Do you like living in Florida?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 3: Do you like living in Florida?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandra Harris. Sandra is a music teacher. She lives with her husband and two children in Miami, Florida. Sandra, it's nice to have you back with us.
Sandra: It's nice to be back.
Kathy: Do you like Florida? Do you like living in Florida?
Sandra: Yes, I do. It's a nice place to live.
Kathy: Why do you think so?
Sandra: Well, I love the weather. I like warm, sunny days.
Kathy: What kind of things do you do on sunny days?
Sandra: On sunny days, I like to go to the beach. We live near the beach. We swim in the ocean, and my daughter, Collette, loves to go surfing.

comprehensionitem.question: What's the weather like in Florida?
option: warm in the summer and cold in the winter

comprehensionitem.question: What does Sandra like to do on sunny days?
Who likes to surf?

grammaritem.question: Do you like ______ in Florida?
What kinds of things _________ on sunny days?
My daughter loves _____ surfing.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Is it often warm and sunny in Florida?
Sandra: Yes, it is sunny most of the time. Of course, sometimes it's cloudy or rainy.
Kathy: What do you do when the weather is bad?
Sandra: I like to stay home and read a good book, or watch a video.
Kathy: What else do you like to do?
Sandra: Well, my husband, Bob, and I have a sailboat. On windy days, we like to go sailing.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0303B_Q1.mp3|Is it always warm and sunny in Florida?
option: It is sunny most of the time, but not always.
comprehensionitem.answer: It is sunny most of the time, but not always.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0303B_Q2.mp3|What does Sandra do when the weather is bad?
NDE0303B_Q3.mp3|When do Sandra and Bob like to go sailing?

grammaritem.answer: It is sunny most of the time.
What do you do when the weather is bad?
On windy days, we like to go sailing.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Does it ever rain in Florida?
Sandra: Yes, it does. It sometimes rains. And of course, sometimes we have big storms... hurricanes.
Kathy: Does it ever get cold in Florida?
Sandra: Sometimes, but not very often. In Florida, the weather is almost always warm.... even when it rains.
Kathy: How about snow? Does it ever snow in Florida?
Sandra: Not in Miami, where we live. It never snows in Miami. It's too warm.

comprehensionitem.question: Does it ever rain in Florida?
What's the temperature like when it rains in Florida?
How often does it snow in Miami?
option: It almost never snows in Miami.

grammaritem.question: Does it ____ get cold in Florida?
It never _____ in Miami.
Sometimes it gets cold, but not very _____.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm on Wisconsin Avenue in Georgetown. Excuse me.
Woman: Yes...
Kent: I'm Kent Moss, the New Dynamic English Man on the Street. Do you mind if I ask you a few questions?
Woman: No, not at all.
Kent: Are you on your way to work?
Woman: Yes, I am. I'm walking to work.
Kent: Do you always walk to work in the morning?
Woman: When the weather is good, I usually walk to work. On rainy days, I take the bus.
Kent: Do you walk home at night, too?
Woman: Yes, I do, except in winter. In the winter, the sun sets early, so it gets very dark. I don't like to walk after dark. So in the winter, I take the bus home at night.
Woman: But I usually walk to work in the morning.
Kent: Isn't it cold in the winter?
Woman: Yes, it is, but it's not too cold to walk. It helps me to wake up. And it only takes me 20 minutes to walk to work.
Kent: What do you do when it snows?
Woman: When it snows, I take the bus.
Kent: Do you ever drive? Do you ever drive to work?
Woman: No, never. There's too much traffic. And I can't find a parking place!
Kent: Thank you for taking the time to talk with me.
Woman: My pleasure.

comprehensionitem.question: How does the woman usually get to work?
What does she do when it rains?
How long does it take her to walk to work?

grammaritem.question: __ you mind if I ask you a few questions?
Do you always ____ to work in the morning?
It _____ me 20 minutes to walk to work.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 4: I work with small children.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Doctor Sara Scott. Welcome back, Sara.
Sara: Nice to see you again.
Kathy: How's your sister?
Sara: My sister Chris? Oh, she's fine. She's back home in Chicago.
Kathy: Do you like living in Chicago?
Sara: Yes, but I don't like the weather. It's very cold in the winter. And we get lots of snow.
Kathy: It's very windy in Chicago, isn't it?
Sara: Yes, it is. They call Chicago the Windy City.

comprehensionitem.question: Where do Sara and her sister live?
What does Sara think about the weather in Chicago?
What do they call Chicago?

grammaritem.question: Do you like living __ Chicago?
I don't ____ the weather in winter.
It's very cold __ the winter.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Why do you stay in Chicago?
Sara: Well, my parents live here.
Kathy: Oh, what do they do?
Sara: My father is retired. My mother is a nurse. She works in a small clinic.
Kathy: You work in a hospital, don't you?
Sara: That's right. I work mostly with children.
Kathy: With children?
Sara: Yes, children with medical problems.
Kathy: Can you give us an example?
Sara: Certainly. Most children learn to read when they are five or six. But some don't. Sometimes they have problems with their eyes or their ears.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0304B_Q1.mp3|Who is a nurse in a small clinic?
NDE0304B_Q2.mp3|Where does Sara work as a doctor?
NDE0304B_Q3.mp3|Does Sara usually work with adults or with children?

grammaritem.answer: My father is retired, and my mother is a nurse.
You work in a hospital, don't you?
Most children learn to read when they are five or six.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Sara: I work mostly with children.
Kathy: With children?
Sara: Yes, children with medical problems.
Kathy: Can you give us an example?
Sara: Certainly. Most children learn to read when they are five or six. But some don't. Sometimes they have problems with their eyes or their ears.
Kathy: With their ears?
Sara: Yes. Sometimes they have a hearing problem. Something is wrong with their ears, and they can't hear very well. And when children can't hear very well, they have trouble reading.
Kathy: So you help these children. Very interesting work!

comprehensionitem.question: When do most children learn to read?
option: when they are five or six years old
when they are in fifth or sixth grade
comprehensionitem.answer: when they are five or six years old

comprehensionitem.question: Why don't some children learn to read?
option: They have problems with their eyes or their ears.
They know how to read and write.
comprehensionitem.answer: They have problems with their eyes or their ears.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of medical problems does Sara help with?

grammaritem.question: Something is _____ with their ears.
They can't ____ very well.
When children can't hear very well, they ____ trouble reading.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Hello, Jenny. It's nice to meet you.
Jenny: It's nice to meet you too, Kathy. Max, it's nice to meet you.
Max: A pleasure.
Kathy: You're a model, aren't you?
Jenny: That's right.
Kathy: What kind of model are you?
Jenny: I'm a fashion model. I model clothes.
Kathy: Are your pictures in magazines?
Jenny: Yes, they are. In magazines and newspapers.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of work does Jenny do?
What does a fashion model do?
option: Fashion models wear new clothes in pictures.
comprehensionitem.answer: Fashion models wear new clothes in pictures.

comprehensionitem.question: Where can you see Jenny's pictures?

grammaritem.question: Max, it's ____ to meet you.
______ a model, aren't you?
___ your pictures in magazines?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Do you like modeling?
Jenny: Yes, I like it a lot. And the pay is very good.
Kathy: Do you travel a lot?
Jenny: Not very much. I don't like to travel. I like to be with my family.
Kathy: You have a son, don't you?
Jenny: Yes, I have one son. He's five years old. His name is Jason.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0305B_Q1.mp3|Does Jenny like modeling?
option: Yes, she likes it a lot.
No, she doesn't like to model.
comprehensionitem.answer: Yes, she likes it a lot.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0305B_Q2.mp3|Is Jenny well paid as a fashion model?
option: No, she is not well paid.
Her pay is not very good.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0305B_Q3.mp3|How often does she travel?

grammaritem.answer: I like to be with my family.
You have a son, don't you?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Jenny, I see that you're tall. Are most models tall?
Jenny: Well, many models are tall, but not all of them are tall. Some models are short.
Kathy: What about weight? Are most models thin?
Jenny: No. As you can see, I'm not very thin.
Kathy: But many models are thin, aren't they?
Jenny: Of course, some models are very thin.
Kathy: In my opinion, some models are too thin.
Jenny: I agree. Some models are too thin. They look like toothpicks!
Kathy: Yes, that's right, Jenny.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Jenny look like?
Are all fashion models tall?
option: Most are, but some of them are not.
No. Most models  are not tall.
comprehensionitem.answer: Most are, but some of them are not.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Jenny think about fashion models?
option: Some of them are too thin.
Some of them are too tall.
Some of them are too short.
comprehensionitem.answer: Some of them are too thin.

grammaritem.question: Are most ______ tall?
Many models are thin, aren't ____?
Some models are ___ thin. They look like toothpicks!

mainlistitem.desc: What do you do in your free time?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 6: What do you do in your free time?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Henry Thornton. Hello, Mr. Thornton. Welcome back to our show.
Henry: It's my pleasure to be here.
Kathy: You live in Seattle, don't you?
Henry: That's right.
Kathy: Do you like Seattle?
Henry: Yes, I do, but it rains a lot.
Kathy: I was wondering, what do you do in your free time?
Henry: In my free time?
Kathy: That's right. When you're not working. What do you do when you're not working?
Henry: Oh, I go out to dinner, usually with friends.

comprehensionitem.question: How does Henry feel about Seattle?
option: He would like to live there.

comprehensionitem.question: What's the weather like in Seattle?
What does Henry like to do in his free time?
option: He likes to go out to dinner.
He likes to cook for his friends.
comprehensionitem.answer: He likes to go out to dinner.

grammaritem.question: You live in Seattle, _____ you?
I like Seattle, ___ it rains a lot.
What do you do when you're not _______?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: When you go out to dinner, where do you usually go?
Henry: What kind of restaurant?
Kathy: That's right.
Henry: Well, I usually go to a steak house.
Kathy: When you go to a steak house, what do you usually eat?
Henry: Steak, of course!
Kathy: What else do you do in your free time?
Henry: Well, I spend a lot of time in my house.
Kathy: What do you do when you're at home?
Henry: Well, I listen to music. I also like to work in my garden.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0306B_Q1.mp3|What does Henry like to eat when he goes out to dinner?
NDE0306B_Q2.mp3|How much time does Henry spend at home?
NDE0306B_Q3.mp3|What does Henry do when he's at home?
option: listen to music and work in the garden
comprehensionitem.answer: listen to music and work in the garden

grammaritem.answer: When you go out to dinner, what do you eat?
What else do you do in your free time?
What do you do when you're at home?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: What do you do when you're at home?
Henry: Well, I listen to music. I also like to work in my garden.
Kathy: What do you do when it's raining?
Henry: Well, I stay inside and watch TV. I like to watch the news.
Kathy: Do you like to travel?
Henry: No, I don't. I don't like to travel. I don't like airplanes. When I'm in an airplane, I'm very uncomfortable.
Kathy: So you don't like to fly.
Henry: No, I don't.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Henry like to do when it's raining?
What does he like to watch on TV?
How does Henry feel about travelling?
option: He prefers to travel by airplane.
He prefers to take the train.

grammaritem.question: What do you do ____ it's raining?
I don't like _________.
____ I'm in an airplane, I'm very uncomfortable.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm standing inside the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. Excuse me, sir?
Guard: Yes.
Kent: Do you work here?
Guard: Yes, I do. I'm the security guard. I work here every night.
Kent: What do you do?
Guard: Mostly I help visitors and answer questions about the Lincoln Memorial.
Kent: I think the Lincoln Memorial is the most beautiful building in Washington.
Guard: Many people think so.
Kent: Especially at night, when the lights are on.
Guard: Well, it's seven o'clock now. It's time to turn on the lights. Do you want to see?
Kent: I sure do.
Guard: OK. Here's the control panel. When I push this button, the outside lights go on. See?
Kent: Yes. What happens when you turn this knob?
Guard: This knob controls the lights on the statue of Abraham Lincoln. When I turn the knob this way, the lights get stronger. When I turn it the other way, the lights get weaker.
Kent: Oh, the building looks so beautiful when the lights are on!
Guard: I think so too. Please take your time and look around.
Kent: Thank you.
Guard: You're welcome.

comprehensionitem.question: When is the Lincoln Memorial most beautiful?
What time does the guard turn on the lights?
What does the knob do?
option: It makes the lights on the statue stronger and weaker.
It turns the inside lights on and off.
comprehensionitem.answer: It makes the lights on the statue stronger and weaker.

grammaritem.question: I think it is the ____ beautiful building in Washington.
What happens when you ____ this knob?
The building _____ so beautiful when the lights are on!

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Max: Who's our guest today?
Kathy: Today's guest is Maria Alvarez.
Max: She manages a clothing store, doesn't she?
Kathy: That's right. In San Jose, California.
Max: And what's our topic for today?
Kathy: Today, we're going to talk about food.
Max: Food? Good. I like to talk about food.
Kathy: OK, Max, what's your favorite food?
Max: I'm a meat eater. I like beef, especially steak. How about you, Kathy? What do you like to eat?
Kathy: Oh, I like fish, especially swordfish. Do you like fish, Max?
Max: No, I don't like fish very much.

comprehensionitem.question: Who loves meat, especially steak?
What is Kathy's favorite food?
How does Max feel about fish?
option: He doesn't like it very much.
comprehensionitem.answer: He doesn't like it very much.

grammaritem.question: I like ____, especially steak.
What do you like __ eat?
I don't like fish _________.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. Maria lives in San Jose, California. Hello, Maria.
Maria: Hello, Kathy. Nice to see you again.
Kathy: Today we're going to talk about food. Maria, do you like American food?
Maria: American food?
Kathy: Yes. Steak, hamburgers, and so on.
Maria: Well, I like American food, but it's not my favorite kind of food.
Kathy: What is your favorite kind of food?
Maria: Italian. I love Italian food.
Kathy: So you like spaghetti and pizza, right?
Maria: Oh, yes. I love pizza!
Kathy: How about Mexican food? Do you like Mexican food?
Maria: Yes, I do. My parents are both from Mexico. And they're both excellent cooks.
Kathy: What do they cook?
Maria: Oh, they cook all kinds of Mexican food: enchiladas, tacos, tamales.
Kathy: How about you? Do you cook Mexican food?
Maria: Sure... but I prefer my mother's cooking.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0307B_Q1.mp3|What is Maria's favorite kind of food?
NDE0307B_Q2.mp3|What kind of food do Maria's parents cook?
NDE0307B_Q3.mp3|Enchiladas, tacos, and tamales are examples of what kind of food?

grammaritem.answer: What's your favorite kind of food?
My father and my mother are both excellent cooks.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Do you like Chinese food?
Maria: Yes, I do. I like Chinese food very much. I often go to Chinese restaurants with my friends.
Kathy: What other kinds of food do you like?
Maria: I like Indian food.
Kathy: Indian food is pretty hot.
Maria: Do you mean, spicy hot?
Kathy: Yes. Spicy hot.
Maria: Oh, I like hot food.
Kathy: What kinds of food don't you like?
Maria: Well, I don't like Thai food.
Kathy: Why not?
Maria: Thai food is really hot! It's too hot for me!

comprehensionitem.question: How does Maria feel about Chinese food?
option: She doesn't like it very much.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these kinds of food is not spicy hot?
What kind of food is too hot for Maria?

grammaritem.question: I often go to _______ restaurant with my friends.
What kinds of food _________ like?
Thai food is ___ hot for me!

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Today's guest is John Harris.
Max: I remember John. He's Bob Harris's son, isn't he?
Kathy: That's right.
Max: And what's our topic today?
Kathy: Today we're going to talk about sports.
Max: I know you're a big baseball fan, Kathy.
Kathy: That's right. Baseball is my favorite sport. What about you? Do you like baseball?
Max: Not very much. I prefer football.
Kathy: Do you mean American football?
Max: That's right. I mean American football, not soccer.
Kathy: Do you play football?
Max: Play it? No. I only watch it on television.

comprehensionitem.question: Who is John's father?
What is Kathy's favorite sport?
Which does Max like better-watching football or playing football?
option: He prefers to watch football on television.
He doesn't like football. He prefers baseball.
comprehensionitem.answer: He prefers to watch football on television.

grammaritem.question: Baseball is my ________ sport.
Do you ____ football?
I only watch it __ television.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is John Harris. John is a high-school student. Hi, John.
John: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: Today we're talking about sports. Your favorite sport is gymnastics, isn't it?
John: Yes, it is. I love gymnastics. I practice every day at school.
Kathy: Do you like any other sports?
John: Well, I like basketball. I play basketball with my friends.
Kathy: How about baseball?
John: I play baseball sometimes, but I don't like it very much.
Kathy: Oh, why not?
John: It's too slow for me. I like more action.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0308B_Q1.mp3|What is John's favorite sport?
NDE0308B_Q2.mp3|Does John ever play basketball?
option: He sometimes play with his friends.
comprehensionitem.answer: He sometimes play with his friends.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0308B_Q3.mp3|What doesn't John like about baseball?

grammaritem.answer: Your favorite sports is gymnastics, isn't it?
Do you like any other sports?
I play basketball with my friends.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: How about tennis, John? Do you play tennis?
John: I play a little, but I'm not very good. Sometimes I play tennis with my sister, Collette.
Kathy: How good is she?
John: She's pretty good.
Kathy: Does she usually win when you play?
John: Yes, she does. She usually beats me.
Max: John, do you play golf?
John: No, I don't. I don't know how to play golf.
Max: Do you ever watch golf on TV?
John: No, I don't. I think it's boring. I don't like to watch sports on television.

comprehensionitem.question: Who is better at tennis, John or his sister Collette?
Does John know how to play golf?
option: No, he doesn't, but he likes to watch golf.

comprehensionitem.question: How does John feel about watching sports on television?
option: He doesn't like to watch sports on TV.
He likes to watch baseball and golf on TV.
He likes to watch sports on TV, but he prefers to play.
comprehensionitem.answer: He doesn't like to watch sports on TV.

grammaritem.question: I play tennis ________, but I'm not very good.
Does your sister usually ___ when you play?
I don't ________ to play golf.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 9: Can you play the piano?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Today's guest is Chris Scott.
Max: Sara Scott's sister?
Kathy: That's right. She's a ballet dancer. Do you remember her?
Max: Oh, yes. Is she going to talk about dancing?
Kathy: Yes. Dancing and some other things.
Max: What about you, Kathy? Do you like to dance?
Kathy: Yes, I do.
Max: Are you a good dancer?
Kathy: I'm not bad. I'm a pretty good dancer. You like to dance, don't you, Max?
Max: Well, I like to dance, but I'm not a very good dancer.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Chris Scott do?
option: She's the director of a ballet company.

comprehensionitem.question: Is Kathy a good dancer?
How about Max? is he a good dancer?
option: He's not a very good dancer.
comprehensionitem.answer: He's not a very good dancer.

grammaritem.question: __ you like to dance?
Are you ______ dancer?
I like to dance, ___ I'm not a very good dancer.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Chris Scott. Chris is a ballet dancer. She lives in Chicago with her sister Sara. Hello, Chris. Welcome back to our show.
Chris: It's nice to be here.
Kathy: Chris, I'd like to talk to you about your dancing.
Chris: Certainly.
Kathy: Do you dance with a ballet company in Chicago?
Chris: Yes, I do. We're a small company, but we're pretty good. We have a great director. She's a wonderful dancer. She dances with the Chicago Ballet.
Kathy: How good are the dancers in your company?
Chris: Oh, some of the dancers are excellent.
Kathy: How often do you practice?
Chris: We practice four times a week for several hours. We're getting ready for a performance next month.
Kathy: Oh, what ballet are you performing?
Chris: We're performing several short ballets.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0309B_Q1.mp3|Who is Chris's sister?
NDE0309B_Q2.mp3|How often to the dancers practice?
option: four times a week for a several hours
several times a week for a four hours
They will begin practicing next month.
comprehensionitem.answer: four times a week for a several hours

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0309B_Q3.mp3|What will the ballet company do next month?

grammaritem.answer: How good are the dancers in your company?
We practice four times a week for several hours.
Do you dance with a ballet company in Chicago?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Chris Scott. She's a ballet dancer. Chris, what's your favorite kind of music?
Chris: Classical music. I listen to classical music all the time. When I dance ballet, I usually dance to classical music.
Kathy: What other kinds of music do you like?
Chris: Well, I like rock music too.
Kathy: Rock music!
Chris: Yes. I like to dance to rock music, when I go out with my friends.
Kathy: How about samba and other kinds of Latin music?
Chris: I like to listen to Latin music, but I don't know any Latin dances.
Kathy: You like music. Can you play a musical instrument?
Chris: I can play the piano. And I can play the guitar a little.
Kathy: How well can you play the piano?
Chris: Pretty well. I can play pretty well.
Kathy: Can you sing?
Chris: No, I can't. I can't sing at all.
Kathy: Not at all?
Chris: No. I'm a terrible singer!

comprehensionitem.question: What is Chris's favorite kind of music?
Which instrument can she play better-the piano or the guitar?
How good singer is she?

grammaritem.question: ____ I dance ballet, I usually dance to classical music.
I like ________ to rock music, when I go out with my friends.
I can ____ the guitar a little.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm at the Washington Zoo. Excuse me?
Linda: Oh, hello.
Kent: Would you like to be on our radio show?
Linda: Sure. That sounds like fun.
Kent: Are these your children?
Linda: Yes. This is Dana. She's three years old. And this is her sister Karen. Karen is six. And my name is Linda.
Kent: Nice to meet you, Linda. I'm Kent. Are you having a good time today?
Linda: Oh, yes. Dana and Karen love the zoo!
Kent: What are their favorite animals?
Linda: Well, Dana likes the smaller animals. She likes the rabbits best.
Kent: What about Karen?
Linda: Karen prefers the larger animals. For example, the lions and the tigers. But she likes the bears best, especially the polar bears.
Kent: What about the monkeys? Do they like the monkeys?
Linda: Oh, they both love the monkeys. Karen wants to have a pet monkey. And Dana wants to be a monkey!
Kent: Well, I hope you all have a good time today! Where are you going now?
Linda: We're going to the Monkey House.
Kent: Well, have fun. And thanks!

comprehensionitem.question: Which child is older, Dana or Karen?
What are Karen's favorite animals?
What kind of animal do both children love?

grammaritem.question: Dana likes the rabbits ________.
Karen prefers the ______ animals.
Karen wants _______ a pet monkey.

mainlistitem.desc: Do you like to read mystery stories?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 10: Do you like to read mystery stories?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Martha Harris. Hello, Martha. You write mystery stories, don't you?
Martha: Yes, I do. Right now I'm writing a story called "A Capital Crime."
Kathy: Your stories usually take place in Washington, D.C., don't they?
Martha: That's right. I live in Washington and I like to write about Washington.
Kathy: Do you like to read mystery stories?
Martha: Certainly.
Kathy: Who's your favorite mystery writer?
Martha: Edgar Allan Poe.
Kathy: What other kinds of books do you read?
Martha: I also like to read books about history. Especially books about American presidents. Right now I'm reading a book about Abraham Lincoln.
Kathy: That sounds interesting.
Martha: Yes, it is.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of stories does Martha write?
Where do most of her stories take place?
What other kinds of books does she like to read?

grammaritem.question: Right now I'm _______ a story called "A Capital Crime."
Do you like to read _______________?
_____ your favorite mystery writer?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Martha Harris. She is a mystery writer and she lives in Washington, D.C. You like to read mystery stories. What else do you like to do in your free time?
Martha: Well, my husband and I take classes at American University, here in Washington. We also like to play cards. We play cards with our friends every Saturday night.
Kathy: What kinds of card games do you play?
Martha: Our favorite game is bridge, but we like all kinds of card games.
Kathy: How about poker? Can you play poker?
Martha: I can't, but my husband can. He's a fairly good poker player. He plays poker with his friends every Thursday night.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0310B_Q1.mp3|What are bridge and poker?
NDE0310B_Q2.mp3|How often do Martha and her husband play cards with their friends?
NDE0310B_Q3.mp3|Who is the better poker player, Martha or her husband?

grammaritem.answer: What else do you like to do in your free time?
We play cards with our friends every Saturday night.
My husband is a fairly good poker player.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Can you play chess?
Martha: Yes, I can. I enjoy playing chess. I'm a pretty good chess player.
Kathy: Does your husband play chess?
Martha: Yes, he does, but he doesn't play very well.
Kathy: Do you ever play chess with your husband?
Martha: Once in a while. But he doesn't like to play with me.
Kathy: Why not?
Martha: I'm too good for him. I always win.

comprehensionitem.question: How good a chess player is Martha's husband?
option: He's not a very good player.
He plays better than she does.
comprehensionitem.answer: He's not a very good player.

comprehensionitem.question: How often do Martha and her husband play chess together?
Why doesn't Martha's husband like to play chess with her?
option: She's not good enough for him.

grammaritem.question: I enjoy _______ chess.
My husband doesn't play chess very ____.
We play chess _____________.

mainlistitem.desc: Do you have a favorite musician?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 11: Do you have a favorite musician?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandy Steele. Sandy is a student at American University, here in Washington. Sandy, what do you like to do in your free time?
Sandy: When I'm not studying?
Kathy: That's right. What do you do when you're not studying?
Sandy: Well, I listen to music. Especially jazz.
Kathy: Do you have a favorite musician?
Sandy: Oh, yes! John Coltrane. My favorite CD is "My Favorite Things" by John Coltrane.
Kathy: So you listen to jazz...
Sandy: And I also play jazz.
Kathy: You're a jazz musician? Aren't you studying science in school?
Sandy: Yes, I am. But I also love music.
Kathy: What instrument do you play?
Sandy: I play the saxophone.
Kathy: Do you play in a band?
Sandy: Yes, I do. Once a month we play at a small club in Georgetown.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of music does Sandy like best?
What is Sandy's favorite jazz CD?
What instrument does Sandy play?

grammaritem.question: What do you do when you're not ________?
__________ studying science in school?
What instrument do you ____?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandy Steele. He's a student at American University. He's studying science and he plays in a jazz band. How big is your band, Sandy?
Sandy: There are four of us. I play saxophone. My friend Tom plays drums. Greg plays bass and Karen plays piano.
Kathy: Are they good musicians?
Sandy: Well, Greg and Karen are both pretty good.
Kathy: What about Tom?
Sandy: Well, he's not the greatest drummer in the world. But he's not bad, and he's getting better.
Kathy: I'd like to hear you play sometime.
Sandy: Sure. Any time.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0311B_Q1.mp3|How many musicians are there in Sandy's band?
NDE0311B_Q2.mp3|What instrument does Tom play?
NDE0311B_Q3.mp3|Which musician is not as good as the others?

grammaritem.answer: Sandy is studying science and he plays in a jazz band.
Tom's not a bad drummer, and he's getting better.
He's not the greatest drummer in the world.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Do you like rock music?
Sandy: I like rock music, but I prefer jazz.
Kathy: Sandy, what kinds of music don't you like?
Sandy: What don't I like? That's easy. Country and Western music. I can't stand Country and Western music. I hate it!
Kathy: But you come from Texas, don't you? People in Texas love Country and Western music.
Sandy: Yes, they do. That's why I don't live in Texas anymore. I don't want to listen to Country and Western music all the time!

comprehensionitem.question: Which does Sandy prefer, rock or jazz?
How does Sandy feel about Country and Western music?
option: He can't stand Country and Western music.
He doesn't mind Country and Western music.
comprehensionitem.answer: He can't stand Country and Western music.

comprehensionitem.question: Why is Sandy happy not to be living in Texas?
option: He hates Country and Western music.
He likes the music in Texas.
He has never lived in Texas.
comprehensionitem.answer: He hates Country and Western music.

grammaritem.question: Sandy ___________ Country and Western music.
People in Texas ____ Country and Western music.
I don't want to _________ Country and Western music all the time.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 12: Can you use the internet?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Today's guest is Denise Collins.
Max: Denise. She was Employee of the Year at her company.
Kathy: That's right. She works at a law firm. She's a receptionist.
Max: She's blind, isn't she?
Kathy: That's right. She's blind. She can't see.
Max: And what's our topic for today?
Kathy: We're going to talk with Denise about her work and her school. Hi, Denise. It's nice to see you again.
Denise: It's nice to be here.
Kathy: I'd like to ask you a little about your work skills.
Denise: Yes?
Kathy: You answer phones and take messages.
Denise: That's right.
Kathy: Can you type?
Denise: Yes. I'm a very fast typist.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these statements is false?
option: Denise works at a law firm.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Denise's job?
How good is her typing?
option: She's fast but she makes many mistakes.

grammaritem.question: She _____ at a law firm.
She's blind. She _____ see.
________ to ask you a little about your work skills.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Denise: I'm a very fast typist. I can also speak to my computer and my computer can write what I say.
Kathy: Really? Your computer can write what you say?
Denise: That's right, if I speak clearly.
Kathy: Is it faster than typing?
Denise: That's a good question. I can type very fast. But I can speak faster than I can type.
Kathy: Does the computer make many mistakes?
Denise: No, not many. And it's getting better all the time!
Kathy: That's very interesting! You're taking classes at night school, aren't you?
Denise: That's right. I'm studying law.
Kathy: Do you use a computer when you study?
Denise: Yes, I do.
Kathy: How?
Denise: I can't see, but my computer can speak to me.
Kathy: So you have a computer with speakers?
Denise: That's right. I can't see but I can hear. I can listen to my computer.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0312B_Q1.mp3|What can Denise's computer do?
option: It can write what she says.
It can say what she writes.
comprehensionitem.answer: It can write what she says.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0312B_Q2.mp3|Does her computer sometimes make mistakes?
option: Yes, it makes a lots of mistakes.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0312B_Q3.mp3|Can her computer speak to Denise?

grammaritem.answer: I can speak faster than I can type.
Does the computer make many mistakes?
I can't see, but my computer can speak to me.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Denise: I can't see but I can hear. I can listen to my computer.
Kathy: How does that help you?
Denise: My textbook is on a CD-ROM. My computer can read the textbook out loud to me.
Kathy: What about the Internet? Can you use the Internet?
Denise: Yes, I can. My computer can also read pages from the Internet to me.
Kathy: So computers really help you!
Denise: Yes. For me, computers are wonderful!

comprehensionitem.question: How does Denise's computer help her read her textbook?
option: The computer can speak the words of the textbook.
The computer can understand the words of the textbook.
The computer can write the words of the textbook.
comprehensionitem.answer: The computer can speak the words of the textbook.

comprehensionitem.question: Can Denise use the internet?
option: No, she can't read the pages.

comprehensionitem.question: How does Denise feel about computers?
option: She thinks they have some uses.
She thinks they are too difficult to use.

grammaritem.question: I can't see but I ___ hear.
My computer can read the textbook ________ to me.
Can you ___ the Internet?

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm at a gymnasium in Washington, D.C. We're watching a Wheelchair Basketball game. Let's speak to the coach. Hello, I'm Kent Moss.
Tom: Pleased to meet you. I'm Tom Lansing.
Kent: I see that all the players are in wheelchairs.
Tom: Yes, that's right. They all have problems with their legs, and they can't walk. But they can play basketball. They are all excellent players.
Kent: I can see that.
Tom: Yes. They can move very quickly in their wheelchairs. And they can throw and catch the ball very well.
Kent: Do you play basketball yourself?
Tom: Yes, I do. As you can see, I can't walk, but I'm a very good basketball player.
Kent: How's the game going?
Tom: Our team is winning.
Kent: What's the score?
Tom: 37 to 32, and it's almost over.
SFX: crowd noise.
Tom: Oh, now it's 40 to 32.
SFX: final buzzer
Tom: That's the end of the game.
Kent: Congratulations on your victory!
Tom: Thank you. It's been nice talking with you.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Tom Lansing do?
option: He coaches a Wheelchair Basketball team.
He is a professional basketball player.
comprehensionitem.answer: He coaches a Wheelchair Basketball team.

comprehensionitem.question: What can't the basketball players do?
Who won the basketball game?

grammaritem.question: They all have problems with their legs, and they _____ walk.
They can throw and catch the ball very ____.
I can't ____, but I'm a very good basketball player.
